source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Two surface finishing techniques were applied during manufacture of the cladding discussed in this paper. Approximately equal numbers of pins were finished by: ( a ) belt-grinding, and ( b ) acid pickling followed by autoclaving at 400°C to give a 1 to 2-μm oxide layer.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Two surface finishing techniques were applied during manufacture of the cladding discussed in this paper. Approximately equal numbers of pins were finished by: ( a ) belt-grinding, and ( b ) acid pickling followed by autoclaving at 400°C to give a 1 to 2-μm oxide layer.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Comparison of the cladding oxidation behavior showed no significant difference in oxide thickness after irradiation but evidence has been obtained that nodules are preferentially nucleated along the scratches produced by the belt-grinding process [Fig. 2 ( a ) ]

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Oxidation measurements have been made on cladding with two types of final heat treatment: ( a ) stress-relieved 4 h at 505°C ,and ( b ) fully recrystallized 1 h at 575°C to produce a fine-grained equiaxed structure with a mean grain size of about 5μm

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Oxidation measurements have been made on cladding with two types of final heat treatment: ( a ) stress-relieved 4 h at 505°C ,and ( b ) fully recrystallized 1 h at 575°C to produce a fine-grained equiaxed structure with a mean grain size of about 5μm

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Evidence from an experiment in which fuel pins manufactured from cladding of both heat treatments were irradiated in the same assembly indicated that under grids there were many more nodules on the recrystallized cladding, but because they were much finer (typically 0.1 to 0.2-mm diameter compared with ~0.5 mm for stress-relieved cladding) the surface coverage was generally less [Fig. 2 ( a ) and ( b ) ]

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_010_chunk2
evidence_span: Evidence from an experiment in which fuel pins manufactured from cladding of both heat treatments were irradiated in the same assembly indicated that under grids there were many more nodules on the recrystallized cladding, but because they were much finer (typically 0.1 to 0.2-mm diameter compared with ~0.5 mm for stress-relieved cladding) the surface coverage was generally less [Fig. 2 ( a ) and ( b ) ]

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_010_chunk2

evidence_span: The well known lenticular form of nodule, with a diameter to thickness ratio of >10:1 predominates in stress-relieved cladding, whereas in recrystallized cladding the nodules tend to occur in a squat form with a diameter to thickness ratio of 1 to 5:1, Fig. 3 ( a )

evidence_span: After mean element irradiation levels up to 15 MWD/kgU, hydrogen levels in the cladding did not exceed 150 ppm and at the more highly oxidized regions near grids the results indicate that 7 percent (σ = 2.5 percent) of the hydrogen stoichiometrically equivalent to the corrosion occurring is absorbed by the Zircaloy

evidence_span: The observation of localized nodule concentrations at Zircaloy grid positions in the mixed-grid experiment is explained by flow disturbance increasing the mass transfer of oxidizing species such as HO₂ to the oxide surface.
